DataElement.preferredName: Metastasis At Diagnosis Assessment Status Malignant Neoplasm Stratification Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The response that answers a stratification question related to the metastasis status of a malignant neoplasm.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. For example, breast cancer cells may spread (metastasize) to the lungs and cause the growth of a new tumor. When this happens, the disease is called metastatic breast cancer._Used to indicate position, location, or state._The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation._Having determined the value, significance, or extent of._A condition or state at a particular time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. For example, breast cancer cells may spread (metastasize) to the lungs and cause the growth of a new tumor. When this happens, the disease is called metastatic breast cancer.

Concepts.definition: The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.

Property.preferredDefinition: Used to indicate position, location, or state.:The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.:Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.:A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: Used to indicate position, location, or state.

The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.
A condition or state at a particular time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for TARGET per request by T.Davidsen and approved for release by D.Barkauskas. mc 4/24/12

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._The process of classifying patients into a sequence of grades or ranks as part of the randomization process or for purposes of data analysis._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having to do with metastasis, which is the spread of cancer from the primary site (place where it started) to other places in the body.

Concepts.definition: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._The process of classifying patients into a sequence of grades or ranks as part of the randomization process or for purposes of data analysis._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The process of classifying patients into a sequence of grades or ranks as part of the randomization process or for purposes of data analysis.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
